text: English pronunciation lesson 11 topic
can and can't part 1 camped listening
task watch and listen how well do you
understand the difference between can
and can't and spoken English
I'll bet you didn't know that I can't
see very well without contacts or
glasses it's true I have very poor
vision on what they call nearsighted
that means I can see clearly when things
are very close but I can't see things at
a distance other people are farsighted
they can see at a distance but they
can't see clearly when objects are close
for example they can't read without
glasses in my case hopefully everything
will change in two days because I'm
going to have eyes surgery the
technology these days is pretty good
because they can correct my vision in
about 15 minutes with the laser I'm a
little nervous
but I can hardly wait for the results so
wish me luck
in this lesson we're going to talk about
two verbs can
and camped let's first talk about the
negative can't is a contraction it's a
short form for cannot the phonetic
transcription for Kant looks like this
Kant is a stressed word no matter where
it is in a phrase or sentence it will
always receive stress so let's note that
Kant is a stressed word in fact it's the
vowel sound that receives the stress
it's going to be long and strong
let's try saying can't in sentence I
can't see this is true without my
glasses or contacts I can't see in this
sentence both verbs receive stress both
vowel sounds here and here are long and
strong I can't see now in everyday
speech Americans often change this
pronunciation to something else what is
that something else
let me explain instead of this final T
Americans take it off and replace it
they take it off and use a glottal stop
instead
the glottal stop is a stop of the
airflow here in your throat so you don't
hear can't you hear can the vowel sound
is still long and strong but I cut off
that T and I cut off the airflow with a
glottal stop now you may be thinking
glottal stop what is that how do I make
it well if you can say where it's like
uh-oh or ah then you're making a glottal
stop oh is an expression of surprise
like you made a mistake
uh huh meaning no don't do that uh oh uh
uh in the middle of those words you have
a glottal stop so if you can say these
you can make the glottal stop in camp
now let's go back to the sentence the
first way is I can't see now with the
glottal stop I can't see I can't see
keep the valve long and strong can't see
but cut off that final T and use a
glottal stop I can't see let's try some
exercises
exercise 1 listen and repeat 1 Jennifer
can't see things far away
- Jennifer can't drive without her
glasses 3 can't she wear contacts
4 no she can't 5 Jennifer can't wear
contacts now because soon she'll have
eye surgery
exercise to complete the statements use
your own ideas number one I wish I could
but I can't for example I wish I could
sing well but I can't number two when I
was a child I was able to but I can't
anymore
in my case when I was a child I was able
to do gymnastics but I can't anymore and
three there's one law I don't agree with
it states that you can't I'll let you
think about that and give your own
answer end of part one please go on to
the next part of this lesson
